title: Joshua's Covenant Renewal
shortSummary: Joshua gathers all Israel at Shechem to recount God's faithfulness from Abraham to their present possession of the Promised Land. He calls the people to choose whom they will serve, leading to a solemn covenant renewal to serve the LORD alone. The chapter concludes with Joshua's death and the reaffirmation of Israel's commitment to God.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Conquest and Settlement of Canaan

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Leader of Israel who calls the tribes to renew their covenant with God and reminds them of His faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: Patriarch of Israel mentioned as the starting point of God's covenant promises.

keyCharacters.name: Balak
keyCharacters.description: King of Moab who opposed Israel and sought Balaam to curse them, illustrating God's protection over Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Balaam
keyCharacters.description: Prophet hired by Balak to curse Israel but instead blesses them by God's intervention.

definitions.definition: Refers to the Euphrates River; 'the other side of the flood' means Mesopotamia, the ancestral homeland of Abraham.
A solemn agreement between God and His people involving commitments and promises.
A description of God's holy zeal for exclusive devotion, intolerant of idolatry or divided loyalty.
A significant city in Canaan where Joshua convened Israel to renew their covenant with God.

outline.heading: Joshua Calls Israel to Shechem and Reviews God's Faithfulness
outline.description: Joshua gathers the tribes and recounts God's mighty acts from Abraham’s call, the Exodus, conquest victories, and provision of the land, emphasizing God's sovereign hand throughout Israel’s history.

outline.heading: The Call to Choose Whom to Serve
outline.description: Joshua challenges the people to fear the LORD and reject false gods, presenting a clear choice between serving the LORD or other gods, to which the people respond affirmatively to serve the LORD.

outline.heading: Warning Against Unfaithfulness and Covenant Confirmation
outline.description: Joshua warns that serving the LORD requires holiness and warns of consequences for idolatry. The people reaffirm their commitment, and Joshua sets a stone as a witness to the covenant.

outline.heading: Joshua’s Death and Legacy
outline.description: The chapter closes with the death and burial of Joshua and Eleazar, noting Israel’s continued faithfulness during their leadership and the burial of Joseph’s bones in Shechem.

application: Regularly remember and recount God's faithfulness in your life to strengthen your trust and obedience.
Make a deliberate, personal choice to serve the LORD wholeheartedly, rejecting all forms of idolatry.
Understand that serving God requires sincerity, truth, and holiness, and be aware of the consequences of turning away.
Establish tangible reminders of your commitment to God to encourage ongoing faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: And if it seem evil unto you to serve the LORD, choose you this day whom ye will serve; whether the gods which your fathers served that were on the other side of the flood, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land ye dwell: but as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the pivotal choice of allegiance and Joshua’s personal declaration of faithfulness, challenging believers to make a deliberate commitment.

keyVerses.text: And the people said unto Joshua, The LORD our God will we serve, and his voice will we obey.
keyVerses.significance: This verse expresses Israel’s public and solemn commitment to serve and obey God, highlighting the importance of obedience in the covenant relationship.

keyVerses.text: And Joshua said unto the people, Ye cannot serve the LORD: for he is an holy God; he is a jealous God; he will not forgive your transgressions nor your sins.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God's holiness and jealousy, warning that serving Him requires exclusive devotion and recognizing the seriousness of sin.
